Most Illustrious Sir

With the damages I suffered after the concordat I obtained on September 15, 1831, I was almost unable to fulfill exactly the obligations I had contracted by it, and now, because of the political movements that have taken place in the Province, not only do I find myself entirely deprived of the power to put such duties into action, but also, if at such a time I tried to sell the existing goods, beyond not finding anyone to purchase them, they would be valued so low that it would amount to a total loss, thus causing serious damage to my creditors and to myself in particular. In view of so many reasons, I dare to beg Your Lordship

May God keep Your Lordship Pelotas, November 16, 1835. From Your Lordship, Domingos Jos√© de Almeida.

Most Illustrious Sir. Examining the contents of your letter of the sixteenth of the current month, I answer that, on my part, I agree to your proposition. Pelotas, November 24, 1835. Your very attentive admirer and servant Guilherme Rodrigo de Carvalho.

Most Illustrious Sir. [On the back] City of Pelotas.

Answered.
